DEVELOPMENT SUPPORT SERVICES

STRENGTHENING SOCOTRA'S POLICY AND REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR MAINSTREAMING BIODIVERSITY

title.narrative: Dragons Blood Tree in Socotra Island

description.narrative: Supporting Socotra Island in policies development for preservation of unique biodiversity
capital of a political entity
first-order administrative division
Environment - policy, planning and administration

Biodiversity management considerations are mainstreamed effectively into the current process of â€œdecentralizing governance for developmentâ€? on the Socotra archipelago
Sustainable natural resources management and protection of Socotra Archipelago ecosystems

Mainstreaming Impacts:
Socotra spatial plans incorporates biodiversity information provided by EPA-SCDP
Number of public and private sector developments in breach of the spatial plan
Four new MPAs established and management plans developed

comment.narrative:
Spatial planning system is not effective
Three MPAs established and operational

Compliance with all spatial planning decisions by Island Wide and District Administrations
Seven MPAs fully operational

Establishment of Socotra integrated coastal zone management board, legal offices, governor decision to research department to be responsible of mainstreaming biodiversity consideration to governorate strategic planning. Capacity building to governorate offices in GIS system based on environmental data and the project help in solving some environmental issues such as eradication of new introduction of Indian house crow and introduction of beehives. The project also becomes more clear after reviewing of his loge frame with help on international part-time technical advisor.
Compliance with all spatial planning decisions by Governorate and Districts Administrations
The update of the tracking tool was due in June 2014 and will be conducted with delay

description.narrative:
Biological Impacts:
Distribution and population estimates of Socotra Cisticola

comment.narrative: Population estimated at 8,000 individuals from surveys made 1999 - 2004.
In year 5, same as or greater than baseline estimate i.e. no net decline in Cisticola numbers or distribution.

The monitoring of Cisticola population program was done on March 2015 and will be conducted as soon as possible.
The program was has been developed based on bird atlas map in cooperation between EPA and Birdlife International. The implementation of the program has been delayed and will be initiated in the following reporting period.

description.narrative: Local Governance Support

Local Governance Impacts:
Island wide administration operational and working on integrated manner with local, national and international stakeholders

comment.narrative:
Limited coordination between multiple individual Ministries & de-concentrated branches of central Authorities, from the Governorate, Local District Councils, powerful individuals/ private sector initiatives
District level local authorities are not operating in an integrated manner and with weak capacities in mobilising resources, managing public expenditures and promoting local economic development

New Island Wide local governance structure approved by end of Year 2 with appropriate coordination mechanism & advocacy in place (central & local)
Single strategic planning body (at the local level) undertaking integrated planning on Socotra by end of Year 3.
New local district authority structures in Socotra aligned with national decentralisation strategy and working in an integrated manner with Island wide governance structures
District local administration with enhanced capacities to mobilise resources, manage public expenditures, promote local economic development and tourism in line with relevant international commitments (World Heritage Status)

Management Development Research and Training Division (MDRT) within governor office partly plays the role of strategic planning unit (governor decision). The divisions also representing the governorate in supervising the information counter. Currently there is still a discussion with stakeholders for the best way of integrating biodiversity consideration into strategic planning. The National Integrated coastal zone management board established and will enhance strategic planning and coordination. Developing the financial capacity of new governorate of Socotra training course entitled “Prepare the budget for Socotra Archipelago and its Environmental Indicators” hold in EPA Socotra with 40 trainees from different government agencies. More work is the creating strategic planning unit and it functionality.

description.narrative: EPA functional assignment on Socotra

comment.narrative: EPA carrying out community development initiatives beyond its mandate Jointly responsible for enforcing the CZP with the Ministry of Public Works & Roads

EPA working within its mandate and in a manner which is fully coordinated with other local authority functions providing technical environmental input to an island-wide integrated planning process
EPA delegated authority to enforce and monitor environment obligations under the spatial plan by end of Year 4

The roles of EPA and Governorate in terms of biodiversity conservation have been clarified through establishing Socotra Integrated Coastal Zone Management Board for implementing National Integrated Coastal Zone Management Strategy (2 days’ workshop with 50 participants), as a result of the workshop 20 legal departments have been established within government agencies, this help in clarify the roles and mandates of EPA, governor and other offices in terms of biodiversity conservation.
GIS system at EPA with help of GIS specialist has been established, available biodiversity data have been collected from EPA and others scientist and researchers who worked on Socotra 30 EPA, governor, government agencies staff have been trained in GIS system and its applications for 35 days, and 30 EPA and other government agencies staff soon will be trained for 5 days on environmental legal framework this facilitate transferring of environmental data, laws and legislation to other decision makers for better sustainable development and conservation decisions.

description.narrative:
Training sessions for local authorities and NGOs/CBOs (impact assessment, MPAs management, etc.) organized
Three workshops organized on Surveillance and Control of fishing activities within the MPAs

comment.narrative: Insufficient MCS system and activities.
Improved MCS efficiency and awareness increased
As part of the withdrawn of AFD contribution, this indicator has been deleted from the log frame.

description.narrative: Mainstreaming Tools Provided

Mainstreaming Impacts:
Use of mainstreaming tools provided by the project by strategic planners

comment.narrative: Conservation Zoning Plan only used by EPA

Strategic Planning Unit to prepare necessary tools to mainstream environmental consideration into Island wide planning & decision making processes
Regulations that mandate the local administration to use the planning tools and the EPA-SCDPâ€™s data as part of the Strategic Planning Unitâ€™s development of integrated programmes

Focusing on rising awareness of different stakeholders on Socotra about environmental laws and legislations and CZP the project holds 2 workshops with more than 70 participants discussed the conservation zoning plan first with fisherman and second with local authority. The governor, minister of fishery and other government directors attend those workshops. Conservation zoning plan maps have been re-designed, printed and distributed to several target groups includes government offices, schools, NGOs, hotels and tourism agencies. Awareness campaigns with local authorities, fishermen and other associations and school students continue through individuals and group meetings reached more than 400 individuals. Conservation zoning plan document have been distributed to participants and also have been distributed to other officials through MDRTD staff in total more than 60 copies have been distributed. The national legal advisor started in reviewing existing national biodiversity mainstreaming tools and its compatibility with national laws and legislations. As part of integrating biodiversity conservation considerations to development decision making

description.narrative:
Reports from monitoring missions
Legislation on sustainable fisheries in the Socotra Archipelago recommended
Number of research and monitoring studies conducted by the marine team

comment.narrative:
Inadequate monitoring system for fisheries
Limited equipment available for research and monitoring

Enhanced monitoring tools and system adapted by the relevant stakeholders.
Equipment for monitoring available and used by local authorities and for research.
As part of the withdrawn AFD contribution, this indicator has been deleted from the log frame.

description.narrative: NGO Advocacy Strengthened

Local community biodiversity management impacts:
Number of NGOs/CBOs/ community development associations on Socotra involved in biodiversity management

comment.narrative: 1 NGO actively involved
20 NGOs/CBOs active by end of Year 4 involved

Targeting awareness of local NGOs/CBOs 27 fishermen associations have been targeted for awareness workshop about CZP, women association celebrate the world wetland day, one community group celebrate world wildlife day
Ensuring highlighting key biodiversity conservation priorities 3 campaigns have been organized, first celebration of world wildlife day focusing on biodiversity and ecotourism more than 100 celebrated the events with films on open air, second celebration of national environmental day through giving lectures in the school about important of biodiversity, more than 200 students reached, and third invitation of researchers giving lectures in the university about caves, archeology (rock art), more than 70 students participated.

description.narrative: Capacity of NGOs /CBOs/ community development associations on Socotra to manage biodiversity

comment.narrative: 1 NGO able to function independently
20 NGO/CBOs to function independently by the end of Year 4

The training program have been developed and submitted to UNDP CO, due to current country situation the advertising have been delay. Technical training priorities come as a result of one day work shop with 27 participants represents NGOs/CBOs. Project management and resources mobilization training priorities comes as a result of previous NGOs/CBOs assessment done by the project.
Capacities of local NGOs have been identified as a major constrain to unleash their full potential as partner in the process of mainstreaming biodiversity considerations into the development planning processes in Socotra. As such, project activities relating to NGO capacity building are expected to contribute in strengthening the institutional and technical capacity of environmental NGOs so that they are able to effectively fulfill their potentials in biodiversity awareness raising and conservation. The project has made progress towards this during the last reporting period including preparing of a draft institutional capacity building module based on the NGO need assessment. TORs for contracting a consulting firm has been developed and process initiated for delivery of the service.

description.narrative: Small grants allocated to local NGOs/CBOs by GEF SGP, COMPACT, or other donors

comment.narrative: 1 at start of Year 1 .
20 grants allocated by Year 4

The project has established contacts to GEF SGP regarding the allocation of grants to Socotran NGOs/CBOs. The grants depend on the results of implementing the training program which is delay due to current country situation.

description.narrative: Capacity of Socotra Conservation Fund to act as an Intermediary Support Organisation

comment.narrative: SCF is not capable of acting as an Intermediary Support Organisation
Capacity of SCF to act technically in an autonomous manner as an intermediate support organisation at end of Year 2.
The project log frame has been reviewed and this indicator has been deleted with its associated baselines, targets and assumptions

description.narrative:
Number of training sessions conducted
List of village school teachers and eco-guides trained
Appropriate didactic and awareness materials available (film, booklet, leaflets)
Two exhibitions prepared
International conference organized

comment.narrative:
Lack of awareness on sustainable use of coastal/marine ecosystems
Appropriate/tailor made didactic and awareness materials on coastal/marine ecosystems not available

Increased awareness among local communities on marine biodiversity and sustainable natural resources management
Didactic and awareness materials on marine biodiversity produced and disseminated
Two exhibitions conducted
International conference organized

Targeting educates children on biodiversity conservation and CZP 4 schools environmental clubs already established during this reporting period 210 students have received environmental lessons, lectures or presentation in 4 schools for three times. 20 environmental articles have been gathered and printed (50 pages in total), 100 CZP’s maps and posters have been distributed to school environmental clubs and 100 CZP’s maps to 10 other schools. Information materials include 5 maps terrestrial and marine CZP, master plan (settlements, fishery, schools and tourism) and 4 posters includes biodiversity, Dragon blood tree, fauna diversity and soil erosion have been printed and distributed to schools, local authorities, government offices and distribution will be continue.
All planned CZP boundaries have been installed on the sites (15 signboards.The information counter has been established as agreement between governorate, EPA and investor, successfully linked with 5 local associations and individual initiatives. The counter includes maps, posters, traditional handcrafts, postcards, books and pictures. The counter help in promoting protected areas, natural conservation, and environmental awareness and also provide tourists with tourism programs and advices.

description.narrative: Strengthened Link Between Biodiversity Local Benefits and Conservation Outcomes

Higher revenues that local administration derive natural resources from exploitative assets of the Island
No. of sustainable private initiatives including SMEs and higher income for local communities resulting from sustainable trade of biological specimens

comment.narrative: Limited benefits for rural communities.

Regulations and enforcement in place to allow private communal initiatives to export biological specimens under certification
Regulations to allow local authorities to mobilize revenues from tourist activities either from incoming tourist or through service providers and guidelines that enable local communities, particularly in rural areas, to benefit from these activities
Regulations to allow GoY and local administration in Socotra to benefit from existing market on biodiversity property rights

First under indicator 1 there are two indicators and both have been revised by PTA during project’s logframe revision, first “Higher revenues that local administration derives from exploitative natural resource assets of the Island”, second “No. of sustainable private initiatives including SMEs and higher income for local communities resulting from sustainable use of biodiversity”
The capacity building program which has been submitted includes five training themes (organization, management, sustainability, governance and environmental protection), this training targeted NGOs/CBOs but also SMEs and will help them on writing project’s proposals, effectively participate in CBNRM and creating and implementing protected areas management plans. Implementing the training program will help the NGOs, CBOs and community to understand financial mechanisms for visitors’ tax and protected areas entry fees. For the first indicator there will be two main activities visitors’ tax mechanisms and protected areas entry fees, these activities will be implemented with support of national legal advisor. The second indicator will includes four activities (awareness, ecotourism carrying capacity, CBNRM and supporting projects’ proposals). Will do this on a competitive basis to simulate real life scenario and apply skills learnt in proposal writing training as part of institutional capacity building program. Applications should contain both, biodiversity conservation and biodiversity-friendly livelihood components and be linked to GEF-SGP.

description.narrative:
Four new campsites constructed and operational with water network and solar systems. Improved facilities in existing campsites
Infrastructures constructed/improved and operational in the five priority MPAs, water network and solar systems operational
Information boards and road panels placed
Demarcation buoys are installed
Maintenance of infrastructure integrated to the management plans
MPAs provided with training and equipment for the eco tourism activities
Trainings conducted for the local communities on campsite maintenance, management and services
Number of monthly visits by the Marine Team to the MPAs
Number of awareness sessions conducted
Two communities in a proximity of MPAs supported in honey production
Women associations from Qalansiya trained and supported in kitchen garden establishment and maintenance

comment.narrative:
Lack of infrastructure facilities in the selected four MPAs
Limited equipment and income generated from eco tourism
Limited capacity to improve livelihoods, e.g. honey production, gardening

Four newly constructed campsites fully operational in sustainable manner
Maintenance of infrastructure included to the MPAsâ€™ management plans
Improved capacities and facilities in place to support local communities within MPAs in income generation from eco-tourism.
Bee gardens established and local capacities improved
As part of the withdrawn AFD contribution, this indicator has been deleted from the log frame

description.narrative: Project Management
Delivering of activities and funds in a timely, effective and transparent manner

comment.narrative: N/A

Project activities carried out in a timely, efficient and transparent manner allowing for justifiable contingencies
Work Plan approved in inception phase

Due to political unrest the board meeting have not done except one virtual meeting through internet communication, Annual and quarterly work plans and budgets have been prepared, and the annual report and quarterly progress reports have been submitted. The project has filled all necessary e-reporting requirements such as Atlas, intranet, PIR and format of quarterly reporting. The project also submits all financial requirements, work plans, budget plans and risk action plan. Other short reporting has been submitted such as communication strategy, school environmental clubs, and success stories. The project indicators such as NGOs current situation have been reviewed. ToRs for the recruitment of additional staff as well as of consultants have been drafted and advertised, 2 national consultants recruited and one international part-time technical advisor for short period for helping the project team especially in reporting.

description.narrative: Support to the fisheries sector structuring, organization and capacity building

Number of training sessions organized for the coastal areas communities.
Documents and didactic tools prepared for the fishermen cooperatives.
Conclusions from feasibility testing of sustainable fishing methods.
Conclusions from feasibility testing of the fisheries bycatch exploitation.
Number of training sessions organized for local authorities.
Number of fishermen and MoFW officials trained.
Construction of a new fish market in Hadibo.

comment.narrative:
Limited institutional and technical capacity of the fisheries sector.
Unsustainable fishing practices threatening marine biodiversity.
No value-added fisheries by-products/fish bycatch systems.
No feasibility studies on fish bycatch exploitation.
Limited technical capacity of local authorities to enforce fishing regulation.
Poor hygienic conditions of the existing fish market.

Improved capacities of fisheries and increased awareness on sustainable fishing practices.
Fish bycatch used for income generation.
Fish market with improved hygiene conditions.
As part of the withdrawn AFD contribution, this indicator has been deleted from the log frame

activity-description.narrative: Beneficiaries of the decisions from the Land and Dismissals Comissions

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. The Land and Dismissals Commissions have capacity to aggregate and dissegrate cases and protect documentation. 2. The Transitional Justice Woorking Group of the National Dialogue Conference has capacity to define appropriate recommendations regarding transitional justice and to improve TJ legislation 3. Representatives of excluded and marginalized communities, such as Al-Houthis, citizens of southern governorates, victims, tribesmen etc. included in consultation process on transitional justice and national reconciliation 4. Staff of MoLA gained knowledge on transitional justice in general and truth commissions in particular and what is important to create relevant laws and by-laws.

comment.narrative: 1. Draft Law on Transitional Justice and National Reconciliation is not adopted 2. The Land and Dismissals Commissions do not have capacity to achieve their mandates. 3. Inexistance of consultations on transitional justice. It is widely percieved that some communities, such as Al-Houthis, citizens from Souther Governorates, victims etc. are excluded from societal processes. 4. CSOs, representatives of government and society in general do not have knowledge on TJ.

R1: 1. The Land and Dismissals Commissions inserted 60,000 files into database and solved up to 20,000 cases. 2. Up to 1,000 solved cases ready to be compensated 3. # of citizens informed on the Land and Dismissals Commissions’ achievements. 4. # of Land and Dismissals Commissions’ employees trained how to solve submitted cases and use attained knowledge in every day work. R2: 1. Partnership with # CSOs to implement activities in local areas created (activities: raising awareness on TJ and the TJ Law, conflict resolution, reconciliation etc.). 2. Up to 10 CSOs submitted project proposals to be funded through small grants fund facility. Up to two projects focusing on women’s needs in TJ submitted to UNDP to be funded through small grants fund facility. R3: 1.Through the TJ survey, up to 2,000 citizens are informed about transitional justice 2. # radio/TV clips on transitional justice created and broadcasted # times 3. # political talk shows on transitional justice organized and broadcasted # times R4: 1. # of consultative events organized and up to 200 citizens participated in consultative events on redevelopment of the draft Law on Transitional Justice and National Reconciliation. R5: 1. # programme concept papers on TJ created and used by CSOs, government of Yemen and investigative bodies to define their own programmes and recommendations R6: 1. up to 20 representatives of MoLA trained in legal drafting focusing on TJ area, international humanitarian law and international human rights law and implement attained knowledge in every day work. 2. Out of 20 representatives of MoLA to become trainers of trainers, 5 are able to independently implement trainings

• up to 30 representatives of NGOs trained in project cycle management, financial management and strategic planning management • Up to 30 representatives of NGOs trained 1) in international humanitarian law and human rights law and 2) how to document and report human rights violations and at least 12 of them document and report human rights violations • # of Yemen specialists trained how to provide psychosocial and (para)legal assistance to people in need and at least 12 of them implement gained knowledge • # of Yemen CSOs trained how to implement community security related activities and UNDP made partnership with up to two CSOs • # of government specialists trained in international humanitarian law and human rights law and implement gained knowledge in every day work • # of victims/witnesses of human rights violations interviewed • # of women and girls victims of war and SGBV interviewed • # of victims received psychosocial assistance (particular focus will be given to women and girls victims of war and SGBV) • # of people in need received (para)legal assistance • Community Safety and Security Plans (CSSP) developed in up to 4 locations • CSSP started being implemented in up to 2 locations • The Land and Dismissals Commissions inserted at least 100,000 files into database. • # of Land and Dismissals Commissions’ employees trained in reparations • # of NGOs submitted project proposals to implement human rights/protection related activities • Needs assessment on security and justice conducted – at least 1,000 participated in needs assessment • # of consultative events organized and at least 100 citizens participated in consultative events on transitional justice, human rights, community dialogue, reconciliation etc. • At least one vocational training organized focusing 100 women victims of war and SGBV • UNDP TJ strategy created • Partnership with # of local and international NGOs to implement activities in local areas signed (activities: document and r

description.narrative: • Update of National Mine Action Strategy to cover 2013 – 2017. • Review and revise SOPs and Training Manuals. • Liaise with GICHD to investigate potential for bespoke upgrade to IMSMA V.6. • Develop and implement formal ‘Mapping Strategy’ to supply accurate ‘Mine Maps’ on demand to external agencies. • Produce Monthly Fact Sheets for the international community. • Number of staff receiving refresher training. • Update and implementation of equipment replacement plan. • Co-chair Yemen Mine Action Technical Working Group (TWG). • Attendance at UNMAS Annual Directors conference (South – South Co-operation). • Non-Technical Survey identifies SHA in Amran, Haijah and Sada'a. Significant Land Release. • 950,000 people safeguarded in Amran, Haijah and Sada'a as SHA are identified. • Technical Survey identifies CHA in Abyan. Significant Land Release. • 430,000 people safeguarded in Abyan as CHA are identified. • Mine/ERW clearance operations of the ‘Legacy’ CHA continues. • Reduction in number of military units individuals are seconded from. • Resolution of disparity between field allowances. • Health of MDD. Vetinary activity. • Effectiveness of MDD after training. • Quality of educational materials. • Local NGO engagement. • International NGO engagement. • Mine/ERW related casualties. • Effective system in place to survey (Phase 1), medically examine (Phase 2), support (Phase 3) and then reintegrate (Phase 4) survivors. • Provision of medical examinations. • Supply of medical and rehabilitation aids. • Support YALS in the reintegration of survivors in the communities, including vocational training at the rehabilitation centres as necessary.

comment.narrative: • National Mine Action Strategy (2009 – 2014) dated May 2008 no longer reflects situation on ground. • SOPs last updated in 2007. • A1. 23,757km2 of land in Amran (1 District), Hajjah (3 Districts) and Sada'a (10 Districts) contains possible suspect hazardous areas (SHA). (Initial estimate is approximately 5%). • A2. Approximately 950,000 people at risk in Amran (1 District), Hajjah (3 Districts) and Sada'a (10 Districts). • B1. 5,659km2 of land in Abyan (8 Districts) also contains possible SHA. (Initial estimate is approximately 5%). • B2. Approximately 431,000 people at risk in Abyan (8 Districts). • C. 136km2 of land identified in July 2000 LIS Legacy remains as Confirmed Hazardous Area (CHA). • D. Mine/ERW clearance staff seconded from 62 different military units. • E. Threat of industrial action due to disparity of field allowances between survey teams and mine/ERW clearance teams. • 8 MDD bred of which 5 are deployed on operations. Indicators: • Health of MDD. Vetinary activity. • Effectiveness of MDD after training. • MRE provided to 1.1638 million beneficiaries (of which 786,359 were female (68%)) in 932 communities as of end 2012. • 24 Mine/ERW casualties in 2012 • 2,2789 survivors surveyed, 1,958 medically examined and 1,993 survivors supported as of end 2012. • Training Manuals last updated in 2012. • IMSMA Version 3.0.190. • No ‘Mapping Strategy’ to support external agencies. • Refresher training last undertaken is ongoing. • Equipment replacement plan.

description.narrative: - # of women and men improved their knowledge pertaining to business creation and development - # of women and men finalized a quality business plan - # of women and men participating in business training - # of youth obtained a financial identity through opening of a bank account - # of youth linked with financial resources and services (access to loan) - # of youth placed - # percentage of women - # of youth who received career guidance support based on Tamheed assessments

comment.narrative: - 48% of the youth are neither in education nor employment or training - Limited resources, employment and access to market opportunities for youth - Weak partnership with the private sector for business development and job promotion - Weak youth business skills - Weak national capacities for economic empowerment and employment creation - Yemen is the lowest in the Gender Gap Index since 2006

• At least 3,300 youth (male and female) benefiting from YEEP sustainable employment creation schemes will develop their business and financial capacities and establish their microbusinesses • At least 850,000 Yemenis indirectly benefit from improved community-based asset rehabilitation, reinforced social cohesion, and awareness to entrepreneurship journeys • At least 700 youth will obtain formal employment and internships through a job placement scheme
• At least 250 entrepreneurs directly benefit from the Business Development Services in Sana’a through mentoring and coaching

11,900 individuals have directly benefited from YEEP’s intervention during 2015, indirectly touching the lives of 83,300 family members with improved livelihoods opportunities. During 2015, YEEP responded to key community priorities: providing self-employment and income, and improving skills for a better future of youth. Cash-for-work was most useful in for populations that lost their jobs and source of income due to the war and in locations most affected by conflict, e.g. the Enma solid waste management pilot led in July 2015 shortly after the city was regained by pro-Hadi troops. 3x6’s proven experience was heavily challenged – its current application based itself upon financial structures, which were heavily disrupted by the war. The compulsory savings component of the approach also proved inadequate during the mounting humanitarian crisis, where participants prioritized meeting their immediate basic needs rather than keep savings with the partner NGO and banking institutions. Nonetheless, the 3x6 approach which was adapted to the local context of Hajjah (bridging community WASH needs) and Taizz (targeting a literate youth population with previous agricultural experience) demonstrated the best results in terms of relevance and commitment/motivation of participants. This indicates that the approach should remain flexible and identify through local stakeholders its best local application. The job placement scheme relies on the capacity of partner SMEs to absorb additional workforce. When the latter struggled, it directly impacted youth trained as they could no longer access employment and internship opportunities. The project was also adversely impacted by donor suspensions and late disbursement of tranches, which halted some activities. This notably affected the Hajjah 3x6 approach and WASH vocational training, as well as the Afkar/Youth Innovation and Creativity Award. Some targeted districts were difficult to access as the conflict spread, e.g. Abs in Hajjah

• Activity 2: Indicators: project review conducted and validated Targets: lessons learnt of livelihoods activities in Saada documented through project review
• Activity 3: Indicators: # of MSMEs established through skills development and capitalisation Targets: 144
• Activity 4: Indicators: project review of 3x6 approach conducted Targets: lessons learnt of 3x6 approach in crisis setting documented through project review
• Activity 5: Indicators: innovative business solutions launched Targets: 10
• Activity 7: Indicators: # of projects supported through Diaspora and private sector partnership Targets: 2

Between January and March 2016, YEEP has created 166 direct employment opportunities for youth, including 27% of women, through the capitalisation of micro-social businesses that contribute to social impact in addition to generating income. Youth also benefited from improved business and life skills through training, coaching and business advisory services provided, that will improve their business resilience. A MoU was signed with the Arab Association in Singapore and a Goodwill Ambassador appointed, Dr Saad ben Taleb, former Minister of Industry and Trade, to promote the Yemen Our Home initiative in Southeast Asia amongst the Diaspora community. Similarly, partnerships have been concluded with Sabafon to directly fund the establishment of a youth-run social business in Sana’a responding to local health needs and outreach to associations/companies pursued to identify areas of mutual interests for in-kind or financial contributions. Through technical assistance, the Business Support Centre established in 2015 finalised its work plan to expand its operations and strategic relevance through prospective studies and developing a one-stop-shop oriented solutions centre for aspiring and existing young entrepreneurs.
During Q2, two projects were funded through the Yemen Our Home initiative by SabaFon and Al Kuraimi with preparations led towards their implementation. the BSC continued to run its programme in Sana'a to support entrepreneurs through innovation-oriented workshops such as the Yemen Business Breakfast.
